nodes.text: Changes in which colleges students attend can substantially reduce income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational income mobility in the United States

We construct near-complete college-level statistics by linking deidentified federal tax records, Department of Education records (1098-T and Pell), College Board and ACT data for cohorts born 1980–1991, focusing on 1980–82 for main results

Key measured variables: parents' mean household pre-tax income averaged ages 15–19 (percentiles), students' individual earnings ranks at ages 32–34, college attendance (assigned by most-attended college age 19–22), SAT/ACT scores and race

We compute college-level parental income distributions and students' earnings-by-parent-income using enrollment-weighted statistics and supplement 1098-T with NSLDS Pell records to reduce missing low-income students
Parental income segregation across colleges is very high (e.g., Ivy-Plus: 14.5% top 1% vs 3.8% bottom 20%); two-thirds of variation in bottom-quintile shares lies within selectivity tiers
Degree of income segregation across colleges is about as large as segregation across childhood neighborhoods (ZIP-code exposure indices are similar to college exposure indices)

Within a given college, differences in adult earnings between students from low- and high-income parents are much smaller than the national parent-child earnings gap: national rank-rank slope ~0.29, within-college slope falls to ~0.10 on average and ~0.065 among elite colleges

Students from high-income families disproportionately attend colleges where students at all parental income levels have higher earnings; cross-college correlation between mean parent income rank and mean student earnings rank of bottom-quintile students is ~0.70

There exists substantial heterogeneity in mobility rates across colleges: many mid-tier public colleges (e.g., CUNY, Cal State campuses) combine large low-income shares with relatively strong top-quintile outcomes, producing high bottom-to-top mobility rates; Ivy-Plus colleges show high upper-tail (top 1%) outcomes but low low-income shares

SAT/ACT scores are strongly predictive of earnings but are unevenly distributed by parental income: very few college students from bottom-quintile families have very high test scores (e.g., among 1300+ scorers, only ~3.7% are bottom-quintile)

We impute missing SAT/ACT for ~26% of college students using state, race, college tier, parent-income strata and validation in five states where testing is universal shows imputation closely matches observed distributions

Estimate of fraction of observed cross-college differences in students' earnings (conditional on parent income, race, and test scores) attributable to causal college effects is about 80% (lambda ~0.8) after controlling for observables and application set; this is baseline assumption for simulations

Counterfactual simulation 1 (income-neutral conditional on test scores, race, state, preserving college size and racial/geographic composition): eliminates variation in enrollment by parent income among students with same test score; reduces overall segregation substantially (closes ~64% of gap toward fully integrated among college-goers) but has smaller absolute effect at most selective colleges (bottom-quintile share at Ivy-Plus rises only from 3.8% to 4.4%)

Income-neutral allocations, assuming 80% causal share, reduce the gap in probability of reaching the top earnings quintile between children from top vs bottom parent quintiles by about 15% (e.g., 22 percentage-point gap reduced by ~15%)

Counterfactual simulation 2 (need-affirmative: give bottom quintile +160 SAT points, scaled linearly to fourth quintile) produces near elimination of parental income differences across college tiers and, with 80% causal assumption, reduces intergenerational persistence among college students by about 25% (up to ~33% if purely causal)

Conclusion: Reallocating which students attend which colleges could substantially reduce segregation and increase intergenerational mobility even without changing colleges' educational programs, but effects depend critically on the causal share of college effects and on limited supply of high-scoring low-income students
